docs.lead_paragraph: As the 98th Congress creaked toward a conclusion, organizations and public officials interested in consumer issues tallied up their victories and defeats, and, somewhat to their surprise, found themselves pleased. ''It's not really too bad a list,'' Esther Peterson, the consumer-affairs adviser to two Democratic Presidents and a persistent critic of the Reagan Administration, commented. ''The best that I can say is that we held the line.'' Consumer activists welcomed passage of the following, among others: Generic Drugs. The manufacturers of unbranded drugs, which sell for less, were given permission to put their products - legitimate copies of patented brand-name drugs - on the market more quickly. A compromise worked out by the well-established but odd combination of a liberal Democratic Representative from California, Henry A. Waxman, and a conservative Republican Senator from Utah, Orrin G. Hatch, forced the issue over opposition from many makers of brand-name drugs. President Reagan has signed the bill into law.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new report forecasts that American families will suffer increasingly negative effects from technological innovation and social change unless society devotes more attention and money to supporting them. The report, ''The State of Families,'' was issued yesterday by Family Service America. The nonprofit national organization, formerly known as the Family Service Association of America, comprises 280 social-service agencies in 40 states that counsel more than 700,000 families. ''Although the trend has been in the opposite direction, government has a role in supporting the family that cannot be abdicated,'' said Geneva B. Johnson, the organization's president. ''The private sector can't begin to provide all the kinds of services that families will need.''

headline.main: STUDY FINDS FAMILY BEARS BRUNT OF SOCIAL CHANGE

docs.lead_paragraph: - In a bold attempt to reassert his leadership, Neil Kinnock, the Labor Party's embattled leader, today vigorously condemned the violence that has marred the seven-month-old miners' strike. Addressing the annual party conference at the end of his first year in office, Mr. Kinnock made a bitter attack on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. He accused her of ''tearing our society apart'' and said she was motivated by ''political vanity on a manic scale.'' But he also sought to balance the resolution, adopted in an overwhelming vote by the conference on Monday, that condemned police violence in the miners' strike without mentioning violence perpetrated by pickets.

headline.main: LABORITE CHIEF ASSAILS MINE STRIKE VIOLENCE

docs.lead_paragraph: FROM King David who is said to have wooed young virgins in the hope of absorbing their vitality to modern-day enthusiasts for fetal lamb cell injections and vitamin E megadoses, people have been trying to stave off aging and death. Now medical researchers are growing more hopeful. They say that medical advances and new insight into aging in recent years point to real progress on several fronts against mankind's most unrelenting enemy. Some of the biological hallmarks of age can, indeed, be delayed, these researchers say, resulting in increased vitality in later years. It is a vigor that will be needed in light of longevity trends.

headline.main: HOPE GROWS FOR VIGOROUS OLD AGE
